abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Agricultural
            Extension Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The project
            achieved most of its major objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was substantial, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, while encouraging results have
            been obtained from the group approach to extension, the full
            advantages will only be realized if JT/JTAs are better
            trained in the principles and techniques of the group
            approach. Second, farmer training needs to be greatly
            expanded with course curriculum designed to provide both
            increased knowledge in new technologies and more fundamental
            principles of agricultural production processes. Third,
            special attention is required to introduce mechanisms to
            strengthen and formalize research-extension linkages.
            Fourth, increased emphasis has to be given to the
            utilization of modern media production technologies. Lastly,
            bidding documents and land availability for physical work
            should be ready before negotiations and pay sufficient
            attention to the implementing agency's capacity to
            supervise the quality of construction works.
